ygData.subject: Re: Patents and suchlike...
ygData.msgSnippet: Ian, First (for those who haven t been following) rtNEAT is the only thing under patent and NEAT is *not* patented.  NEAT is completely in the public domain

Date: Fri, 07 Oct 2005 01:21:57 -0000

From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>
Subject: Re: Patents and suchlike...
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=8kmmB0j4ubvmL0h0-Chw2g-Ttuc7IR48sAJPCZjKjIp7KrnrAAwO
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Ian, 

First (for those who haven't been following) rtNEAT is the only 
thing under patent and NEAT is *not* patented.  NEAT is completely 
in the public domain and you can go make money off of it without 
speaking to anyone.

The patent coverage for rtNEAT is I believe international.  We 
purposefully filed the provisional protection (long before the 
patent) in a way that secured international rights.  

Now you are asking about what exactly is patented.  A patent is a 
very complicated legal document, more like a computer program than a 
research paper.  You can think of it almost like a series of 
variable declarations in different scopes.  The claims the patent 
makes at the highest scope are more broad, and then there are more 
narrow scopes for other claims, and there are some cases where 
parallel (i.e. independet) claims are made.  Therefore, the patent 
does not just cover a single concept, but rather a hierarchical and 
parallel set of ideas.  But the patent definitely concentrates on 
what is *not* obvious.  That you can be assured of.  The patent 
office will not accept "common knowledge," which includes things 
that are obvious.  So it is the non-obvious aspects of rtNEAT that 
are really covered.

Let's be realistic here before I go into what's obvious and what's 
not.  Law always boils down to interpretation, in my opinion.  I 
know people hate this fact, and everyone pounds their fists and 
demands the most objective explanation, but everything from 
constitutions to patents ultimately boils down to interpretation.  
That means you and I can disagree about what's obvious, and a judge 
will decide.  We hope the people who enforce the law are fair-
minded, and that's the best we can hope for.  That is, if something 
is truly obvious, they won't let someone get away with owning it.
But this is an imperfect world and there have been some terrible 
abuses of patent authority, such as certain software companies 
claiming to have their patents infringed by Linux, even though they 
did virtually nothing to bring Linux to fruition.  Still, we hope 
those companies will lose in the end, and the system will end up 
working.

That said, I'll tell you what I think is obvious not obvious in 
rtNEAT.  You are right that "continuous evolution" is pretty 
obvious.  In fact broad ideas are frequently obvious.  Therefore, 
having a broad idea is not a very firm ground for feeling slighted 
by someone else getting a patent related to your idea.  For example, 
I thought of "time travel" as a good idea.  But should I have some 
claim on it if someone actually goes and implements it?  Of course 
not, and the same goes with "continuous evolution."  Therefore, 
broad ideas are generally not what is being patented, and shouldn't 
be.

You brought up some other putatively obvious thing:

1 > - replacing one unfit individual at a time
2 > - picking fit parents
3 > - minimum life if required

I'd agree 1 and 2 are obvious.  In fact, #1 is called "steady state 
evolution," and also is used in a 1,1-ES (evolution strategy), all 
predating rtNEAT.  This idea is certainly not under anyone's 
control.  However, the steady state idea is a lot simpler than the 
point of rtNEAT.  Steady state methods do not general evaluate an 
entire population simulataneously and *asynchronously* as you would 
in a video game.  So really the term "continuous evolution" is 
ambiguous.  It could mean different things.  It doesn't really mean 
anything in particular. 

#2 is certainly obvious in any EA.  But the whole question is how?  
That is not necessarily obvious.  #3 may or may not be obvious, but 
it's obvious enough that it is not what we're patenting.

Now let me tell you some things that aren't obvious.  First, how do 
you pick the one to remove?  Clearly that is not obvious since that 
was one of your questions recently.  And our answer, removing the 
one with lowest adjust fitness, is part of the patent.  If you 
adjust fitness according to a diversity scheme and then use those 
adjustments to pick the worst one for removal in the context of a 
real-time EA, you are getting towards overlapping with our patent.

Other things that are not obvious:  How do you maintain a steady # 
of species in real time?  How do you choose the # ticks between 
replacements (we came up with a very nice equation for this)?  How 
do you assign offspring to species in an equivalent dynamic to 
regular NEAT even though NEAT's fitness sharing equations are based 
on generations?

These are all covered by the patent.  

Now of course it can be argued that any of these is obvious to you.  
That's where we get into interpretation.  But let me just finish by 
giving some of my own subjective opinion on why that doesn't 
matter.  In my opinion, "not obvious" does *not* mean that "no one 
could have thought of it if they had tried to do the same thing."
Probably a lot of people would come to similar conclusions if they'd 
tried to do something like NERO.  That is, what "not obvious" means 
is that you wouldn't necessarily think of it unless you put in the 
trouble to actually implement the system.

And that is as it should be.  The whole point of patents is not to 
reward flashes of ingenious insight, but rather to reward the people 
who put in the hard work figure out how to make some theoretical 
concept (or broad concept) in someone's head actually work.  As you 
say, the devil is in the details.  And I can tell you that while you 
can try to take any one piece of rtNEAT and say, "Hey, I would have 
thought of that," if you take the whole combination of components, 
it took a year of hard work to figure out all the dependencies and 
get something that actually works.  It's one thing to talk in 
theory, but it's no trivial matter to set up a real-time evolution 
system in the form of NEAT inside a video game.  There's a reason 
there has not been a NERO before- and it's not that it's impossible- 
it's that it takes a hell of a lot of work to get all the details 
right.

And that's exactly what we have memorialized in the patent, so now 
no one has to go through that again.  And that's really the spirit 
of what patents are for and how they should work:  They should 
protect the little guy who just spent years of his or her life 
making a working embodiment so that the little guy can't be taken 
advantage of.  It's the working embodiment that creates the value 
for society rather than just the idea alone.  The working embodiment 
not only shows "how" to do it, but it also shows that it has real 
value.  It's not that someone else couldn't have done it; it's that 
those who actually *did* do it deserve to get something for making 
that contribution to society.  Remember, patents are only temporary 
anyway.  In the long run, we all benefit freely from all patents.

There is another aspect of your concern which has to do with small 
detail-oriented ideas like "arbitrary labels."  And that also 
touches on my point above.  Ok, so a number of people may have 
thought of arbitrary labels, but I don't think anyone should be 
upset if someone else actually goes through the years of painstaking 
labor to prove that arbitrary labels in fact work and are worth 
millions of dollars to society.  After all, I could have done that 
myself, but I chose not to.  And now this other person will benefit 
from an idea I may have had.  But that's the point:  The idea is 
hardly a stroke of genius; what's important is the hard work to 
actually show it has real practical value!  That's what a patent 
should be rewarding.

But a connected point is that with something detail-oriented like 
arbitrary labels, such an accomplishment is unlikely to materialize 
because they probably *don't* accomplish anything that is all that 
valuable.  In other words, whatever arbitrary labels do, something 
else can probably do more or less just as well.  That is, they won't 
be making anyone millions of dollars anytime soon.  And if they 
would, then we should be thankful for the person who shows us how, 
because *that* certainly isn't obvious.

One last point:  Since I am on the rtNEAT patent, I am probably 
going to be the one who would advise anyone to prosecute patent 
infringement.  In other words, I'm not going to mess with people who 
are going about their business doing truly independent things.  You 
guys know me pretty well and I am for the free exchange of ideas and 
also for people building on each other's creations, and I am not 
interested in becoming a patent factory that makes money of off 
frivolous infringement lawsuits.

So I hope that I haven't wasted too much time writing virtually an 
essay on the point, but it should clarify some of both what is 
patented in the case of rtNEAT, and what patenting is about in 
general.  The parts that are my opinion are developed over a very 
long patent process and many discussions with the rtNEAT patent 
lawyer, as well as from seeing how dangerous the world is for an 
inventor in general through first-hand experience.

As I said before, nothing should stop the free flow of ideas.  
rtNEAT and *any* university-owned property is always free for 
research purposes, and no one here can steal any implementation that 
you disclose on the group, since there would then be evidence that 
it was your idea after all.  In some cases someone may take a broad 
idea and run with it, but as we seem to agree, broad ideas are 
usually obvious anyway, and it's not usually the broad idea itself 
that is valuable, but rather the embodiment that makes it work.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@y...> wrote:
> Hi Ken,
> 
> 	Like I said, I completely understand that you and even the 
> university have reasons, even pressing reasons, to raise the 
> patent.  As you say, it can be necessary just to protect against 
> other people doing it.
> 
> 	I think my problem might be one of the difference between 
broad 
> concepts and fine details.
> 
> 	e.g. the broad concept of continuous NEAT is to my mind 
obvious.  In 
> fact, I think about the third thing I thought when I first read 
your 
> paper (after "now how does this work?" and "that is clever!") 
was "if 
> I did this, I would do it continuously".
> 
> 	And many of the ideas involved in doing that, are very 
obvious and 
> also not specific to NEAT:
> 
> - replacing one unfit individual at a time
> - picking fit parents
> - minimum life if required
> 
> 	So I would be very uncomfortable if the patent tried to 
cover any of 
> these basic concepts.
> 
> 	OTOH, the devil is in the details, and so also is the hard 
work and 
> the place where a person's talents most show.  So I would never 
wish 
> to stop you protecting your investment in that.
> 
> --
> 
> 	The other side of this is that not everything discussed is 
clearly 
> property of one or other individual....
> 
> 	e.g. arbitrary labels, I invented those!  I distinctly 
remember it 
> was about 10 years ago and I wanted them for GP at the time....
> 
> 	Equally, I completely believe Colin used a version of them 
in one of 
> his old projects...
> 
> 	And that you (Ken) came up with them in the context you were 
> describing yesterday...
> 
> 	So, until about 2 months ago all three of us genuinely 
believed we 
> had a novel, unique and useful invention there.  And either one of 
us 
> might have patented it, to the horror of the others....
> 
> 	...but that's to do with the nature of patent and nothing we 
can control :)
> 
> --
> 
> 	Anyway, you have clarified the situation a lot an reassured 
me 
> somewhat, but can you briefly tell us what is and isn't covered by 
the patent?
> 
> 	Is this patent only in the US?
> 
> 	Ian
> 
> In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
